choices.text: Stratified squamous epithelium without goblet cells
Simple cuboidal epithelium with mucous glands
Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with abundant goblet cells
Transitional epithelium with serous glands

questions.text: The internal lining of the nasal cavity, also known as the Schneiderian membrane, is primarily composed of which of the following epithelial types?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with abundant goblet cells

 

  • The internal lining of the nose is called the Schneiderian membrane, which is a pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (also called respiratory type epithelium). This epithelium contains numerous goblet cells that secrete mucus, helping trap dust and pathogens.
  • Beneath this epithelial lining is the submucous layer, which contains serous and mucous glands whose ducts open onto the mucosal surface, contributing to the moist environment of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Stratified squamous epithelium without goblet cells: Stratified squamous epithelium is found in areas subjected to mechanical stress like the anterior part of the nasal vestibule but not the internal nasal lining. It lacks goblet cells typical of respiratory mucosa.

 

Option B. Simple cuboidal epithelium with mucous glands: Simple cuboidal epithelium) is generally seen in smaller ducts of glands and certain parts of the respiratory tract but not as the main nasal lining.

 

Option D. Transitional epithelium with serous glands: Transitional epithelium is typical of the urinary tract and is not present in the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The internal nasal cavity is lined by the pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (Schneiderian membrane) rich in goblet cells, supported by a submucous layer containing serous and mucous glands.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: The olfactory nerve (cranial nerve I) fibers detecting smell are located at the cribriform plate of the nose.
Parosmia refers to the complete absence of smell sensation.
Kallmann’s syndrome is characterized by anosmia and hypergonadism.
Olfactory tests include Weber test and Rinne test.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about olfactory sensation and its disorders is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The olfactory nerve (cranial nerve I) fibers detecting smell are located at the cribriform plate of the nose.

 

The olfactory nerve (I cranial nerve) fibers pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to detect the sensation of smell in the nasal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parosmia refers to the complete absence of smell sensation: Incorrect. Parosmia is a distorted or perverted sensation of smell where one smell is perceived as another. The complete absence of smell is called anosmia.

 

Option C. Kallmann’s syndrome is characterized by anosmia and hypergonadism: Incorrect. Kallmann’s syndrome is a condition characterized by anosmia (loss of smell) and hypogonadism (reduced gonadal function leading to infertility), not hypergonadism.

 

Option D. Olfactory tests include Weber test and Rinne test: Incorrect. The Weber and Rinne tests are used for hearing assessment, not olfaction. Olfactory tests include smell diskettes, UPSIT (University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test), and CCSIT (Cross Cultural Smell Identification Test).

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Hyposmia refers to decreased smell sensation.
  • Cacosmia is the perception of a bad or unpleasant smell.
  • Common causes of olfactory disorders include nasal polyps, atrophic rhinitis, and head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The olfactory nerve fibers pass through the cribriform plate to detect smell, with anosmia defined as complete loss of smell; Kallmann’s syndrome involves anosmia and hypogonadism, and smell testing includes UPSIT and CCSIT.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 142

choices.text: Olfactory receptor cells send their central processes through the jugular foramen to reach the olfactory bulb.
Axons of mitral cells form the olfactory tract, which transmits smell signals to the prepyriform cortex and amygdaloid nucleus.
Olfactory receptor cells have peripheral processes ending in the hypothalamus for autonomic integration.
The olfactory nerves pass through the optic canal to enter the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the olfactory pathway involved in the perception of smell?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axons of mitral cells form the olfactory tract, which transmits smell signals to the prepyriform cortex and amygdaloid nucleus.

 

The mitral cells in the olfactory bulb receive input from olfactory receptor cells. Their axons form the olfactory tract, which carries the smell sensation to the prepyriform cortex and amygdaloid nucleus, where conscious perception of smell occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Olfactory receptor cells send their central processes through the jugular foramen to reach the olfactory bulb: Incorrect. The central processes of olfactory receptor cells pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, not the jugular foramen, to reach the olfactory bulb.

 

Option C. Olfactory receptor cells have peripheral processes ending in the hypothalamus for autonomic integration: Incorrect. The peripheral process of each olfactory receptor cell ends in the mucosa as cilia that detect odorants; autonomic association occurs centrally at the hypothalamic level, not at the receptor endings.

 

Option D. The olfactory nerves pass through the optic canal to enter the brain: Incorrect. The olfactory nerves pass through the cribriform plate, not the optic canal. The optic canal is for the optic nerve (cranial nerve II).

 

Additional points:

 

  • The olfactory region lies high in the nasal cavity and contains millions of olfactory receptor cells.
  • The sensory receptor on each olfactory cell’s peripheral process is a ventricle with several cilia that detect odorous substances.
  • The olfactory system also has autonomic connections via the hypothalamus.

 

Educational Objective:


Olfactory receptor cells send central processes through the cribriform plate to the olfactory bulb; mitral cell axons form the olfactory tract transmitting smell to the prepyriform cortex and amygdaloid nucleus, with autonomic integration at the hypothalamus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 142

choices.text: Newborns are obligate nasal breathers and rely primarily on the nasal airway for respiration.
The nasal cycle ensures equal airflow through both nasal chambers at all times.
During quiet respiration, most airflow passes through the inferior meatus and olfactory region.
Swelling of the middle turbinate regulates simultaneous breathing and eating in newborns.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and cyanosis that improves transiently when crying. On examination, nasal passage obstruction is suspected. Which of the following best explains the urgency of nasal airway patency in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Newborns are obligate nasal breathers and rely primarily on the nasal airway for respiration.

 

Newborn infants are obligate nasal breathers, meaning they primarily breathe through the nose. Conditions like choanal atresia (nasal passage obstruction) can cause severe respiratory distress or asphyxia if not promptly relieved, because mouth breathing is an acquired skill and not yet established in neonates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The nasal cycle ensures equal airflow through both nasal chambers at all times: Incorrect. The nasal cycle involves rhythmic congestion and decongestion of nasal mucosa causing one nasal chamber to be more patent than the other at a given time, with airflow shifting every 2½–4 hours, not equal airflow through both simultaneously.

 

Option C. During quiet respiration, most airflow passes through the inferior meatus and olfactory region: Incorrect. During quiet respiration, most inspiratory air passes through the middle part of the nose between the turbinates and nasal septum. Very little air passes through the inferior meatus or olfactory region.

 

Option D. Swelling of the middle turbinate regulates simultaneous breathing and eating in newborns: Incorrect. It is the anterior end of the inferior turbinate that undergoes swelling and shrinkage to regulate airflow; the middle turbinate does not directly regulate breathing and eating simultaneously. The nose allows simultaneous breathing and eating by separating nasal and oral pathways anatomically.

 

Additional notes:

 

  • The nasal airflow pattern creates eddies during expiration that help ventilate the paranasal sinuses through the ostia.
  • The nasal cycle is characteristic and varies between individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns are obligate nasal breathers relying on the nasal airway for respiration, making patency of nasal passages crucial to prevent neonatal respiratory distress.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage.
Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.
Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia.
Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic nasal obstruction complains of frequent episodes of dry cough and worsened breathing at night. Pulmonary function tests show mild hypoxemia and elevated arterial pCO₂. Which of the following best explains how nasal obstruction can contribute to these respiratory abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.

 

The nasal mucosa humidifies inspired air to maintain relative humidity around 75% or more. Dry air due to nasal obstruction reduces humidification, leading to impaired ciliary function (which stops within 8–10 minutes at 50% humidity). This impairs mucociliary clearance, predisposing to respiratory infections and reduces effective gas exchange in the lungs, leading to hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage: Incorrect. While the nose filters larger particles using vibrissae and mucus, direct alveolar damage from reduced filtration is less common; smaller particles <0.5 μm bypass the nose normally.

 

Option C. Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids act as a “radiator” warming or cooling inspired air to body temperature, but loss of vibrissae does not cause excessive warming or hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids regulate blood flow to control temperature, but oxygen absorption does not occur in the nasal cavity; oxygen exchange happens in the lungs.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Nasal vibrissae filter large particles (>3 μm), while mucus traps finer particles (0.5–3 μm).
  • Inspired air temperature is rapidly adjusted from cold or hot ambient temperature to near 37°C within one-fourth second.
  • Approximately 1000 mL of water evaporates daily from nasal mucosa, crucial for humidification and ciliary function.
  • Nasal obstruction can impair lung function, causing apneic spells and altered blood gases during sleep.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal obstruction impairs humidification of inspired air, leading to decreased ciliary function and compromised gas exchange, resulting in hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Defective nasal mucosal goblet cells causing decreased mucus production and impaired bacterial trapping.
Impaired ciliary beating leading to stagnation of mucus and failure to clear bacteria from nasal passages and bronchi.
Increased lysozyme secretion causing excessive destruction of normal nasal flora.
Enhanced sneezing reflex leading to frequent mucosal injury and infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with chronic nasal congestion, recurrent sinus infections, and persistent cough. On examination and history, he is diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia (immotile cilia syndrome). Which of the following mechanisms best explains his clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired ciliary beating leading to stagnation of mucus and failure to clear bacteria from nasal passages and bronchi.

 

The mucociliary mechanism depends on cilia beating rhythmically to move the mucous blanket containing trapped bacteria, dust, and viruses toward the nasopharynx for clearance. In immotile cilia syndrome, cilia are defective and cannot beat effectively, causing mucus stagnation in the nose, sinuses, and bronchi, which leads to recurrent infections such as chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchiectasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defective nasal mucosal goblet cells causing decreased mucus production and impaired bacterial trapping: Incorrect. In primary ciliary dyskinesia, mucus production by goblet cells and glands is usually normal; the problem lies in ciliary motility, not mucus quantity.

 

Option C. Increased lysozyme secretion causing excessive destruction of normal nasal flora: Incorrect. Lysozyme (muramidase) is an enzyme present in nasal secretions that helps kill bacteria, but its overproduction causing infection is not characteristic of ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Enhanced sneezing reflex leading to frequent mucosal injury and infection: Incorrect. Sneezing is a protective reflex that expels irritants; enhanced sneezing does not cause recurrent infections or mucus stagnation.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Cilia beat 10–20 times per second, moving mucus at about 5–10 mm/min, clearing the nasal passages every 10–20 minutes.
  • Nasal secretions contain immunoglobulins IgA, IgE, and interferon that help protect against infections.
  • Environmental factors like smoking, infections, drying, and noxious fumes impair ciliary movement.
  • Normal nasal pH (~7) is essential for optimal ciliary and lysozyme function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Defective ciliary motility in immotile cilia syndrome causes mucus stagnation and impaired clearance, predisposing patients to chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchiectasis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 141

choices.text: Anosmia due to nasal polyps
Parosmia related to post-infectious olfactory nerve regeneration
Hyposmia due to allergic rhinitis
Olfactory loss due to intracranial tumor

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of a persistent distorted perception of smell, often describing foul odors that others do not perceive. He recently recovered from an influenza infection. Examination shows no nasal obstruction or polyps. MRI brain is ordered to exclude intracranial pathology. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parosmia related to post-infectious olfactory nerve regeneration

 

Parosmia is a distorted or perverted smell perception, often perceived as unpleasant or disgusting odors. It commonly occurs during the recovery phase of post-influenzal anosmia, likely due to misdirected regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers. Patients typically have no nasal obstruction. However, intracranial tumors should be excluded in all cases of parosmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anosmia due to nasal polyps: Incorrect. Anosmia due to nasal polyps typically presents as a complete loss of smell and is associated with nasal obstruction; the patient here has no obstruction.

 

Option C. Hyposmia due to allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. Hyposmia is partial loss of smell, commonly seen in allergic rhinitis with mucosal edema and nasal obstruction, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Olfactory loss due to intracranial tumor: Incorrect. While intracranial tumors can cause olfactory dysfunction, they usually cause anosmia or other neurological signs; parosmia itself is a specific clinical phenomenon usually post-infectious, though tumor must be ruled out.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The olfactory system requires odorous substances to be volatile and reach the olfactory mucosa unimpeded.
  • Causes of anosmia include nasal obstruction (polyps, turbinate hypertrophy, rhinitis), atrophic rhinitis, peripheral neuritis, trauma to olfactory nerves, and intracranial lesions.
  • Testing olfaction involves presenting common odors (lemon, rose, peppermint) separately to each nostril with eyes closed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parosmia, a distorted perception of smell often occurring after viral infections, results from misdirected olfactory nerve regeneration and should prompt exclusion of intracranial lesions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 142

choices.text: Start broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately to prevent complications.
Prescribe bed rest, fluids, antihistaminics, and nasal decongestants; reserve antibiotics for secondary bacterial infection.
Administer aspirin for fever control and analgesia.
Ignore symptoms as the illness always resolves without treatment in 1–2 days.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with 3 days of nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, sneezing, low-grade fever, and malaise. The nasal discharge was watery. There is no significant past medical history. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prescribe bed rest, fluids, antihistaminics, and nasal decongestants; reserve antibiotics for secondary bacterial infection.

 

The cornerstone of treatment in viral rhinitis includes bed rest, adequate hydration, antihistaminics, nasal decongestants, and symptom control with analgesics (preferably non-aspirin to avoid increased viral shedding). Antibiotics should be used only if secondary bacterial infection supervenes, as indicated by mucopurulent discharge persisting beyond the usual course or systemic signs of bacterial infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately to prevent complications: Incorrect. Viral rhinitis (common cold) is caused by viruses such as adenovirus and rhinovirus. Antibiotics are not routinely indicated and are reserved only when secondary bacterial infections develop, such as sinusitis or otitis media.

 

Option C. Administer aspirin for fever control and analgesia: Incorrect. Aspirin should be avoided in viral infections, especially in children, due to risk of Reye’s syndrome and increased viral shedding. Non-aspirin analgesics like paracetamol are preferred.

 

Option D. Ignore symptoms as the illness always resolves without treatment in 1–2 days: Incorrect. Although viral rhinitis is self-limiting and typically resolves over 2–3 weeks, symptoms can be significant and symptomatic treatment is necessary. Complete neglect may lead to complications.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Common viruses include adenovirus, picornavirus, rhinovirus, coxsackie virus, and others.
  • Incubation period is 1–4 days.
  • Secondary bacterial infections may involve Streptococcus haemolyticus, pneumococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.
  • Complications include sinusitis, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, and otitis media.
  • Similar presentations occur in influenzal rhinitis and exanthem-associated rhinitis (measles, rubella, chickenpox).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral rhinitis is primarily managed with supportive care including rest, fluids, antihistaminics, and decongestants; antibiotics are reserved for confirmed secondary bacterial infections.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 152

choices.text: Start systemic penicillin and administer diphtheria antitoxin, with patient isolation.
Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics and nasal decongestants only.
Perform nasal packing and start oral corticosteroids.
Treat symptomatically with antihistaminics and advise increased fluid intake.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with nasal congestion, nasal discharge, and a greyish-white tenacious membrane visible inside the nose. Attempts to remove the membrane cause bleeding. The child also has excoriation around the anterior nares and upper lip. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start systemic penicillin and administer diphtheria antitoxin, with patient isolation.

 

The clinical presentation suggests diphtheritic rhinitis, which is characterized by a greyish-white tenacious membrane in the nasal cavity that bleeds upon removal. Excoriation of the anterior nares and upper lip is a common sign. The treatment involves systemic penicillin to eradicate the bacteria, administration of diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the toxin, and isolation to prevent spread of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics and nasal decongestants only: Incorrect. While antibiotics are necessary for bacterial infections, diphtheritic rhinitis requires specific antitoxin treatment and isolation; broad-spectrum antibiotics alone are insufficient.

 

Option C. Perform nasal packing and start oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Nasal packing and corticosteroids are not appropriate and may exacerbate tissue damage.

 

Option D. Treat symptomatically with antihistaminics and advise increased fluid intake: Incorrect. Symptomatic treatment alone is inadequate for diphtheritic rhinitis, especially with membrane formation and bleeding.

 

Additional information:

 

  • Primary bacterial rhinitis often occurs in children, caused by organisms like pneumococcus, streptococcus, or staphylococcus.
  • Secondary bacterial rhinitis may follow viral infections.
  • Diphtheritic rhinitis is rare nowadays but important to recognize due to its severity and need for urgent treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheritic rhinitis presents with a greyish-white nasal membrane that bleeds on removal and requires systemic penicillin, diphtheria antitoxin, and patient isolation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 152

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis; start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines.
Viral rhinitis; prescribe bed rest and symptomatic treatment.
Irritative rhinitis; remove offending agent and provide supportive care.
Bacterial rhinitis; start systemic antibiotics immediately.

questions.text: A 30-year-old factory worker presents with sudden onset sneezing, nasal congestion, and watery nasal discharge immediately after exposure to strong ammonia fumes at work. Symptoms improve after leaving the exposure but recur intermittently. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irritative rhinitis; remove offending agent and provide supportive care.

 

Irritative rhinitis is caused by exposure to irritant gases (ammonia, formalin, acid fumes), dust, smoke, or trauma to nasal mucosa. It causes an immediate catarrhal reaction with sneezing, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Removal of the offending agent is the primary management. Symptoms usually resolve quickly unless mucosal damage or secondary infection occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis; start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction and usually has a history of allergen exposure and chronic symptoms rather than immediate reaction to irritant gases.

 

Option B. Viral rhinitis; prescribe bed rest and symptomatic treatment: Incorrect. Viral rhinitis presents with gradual onset and systemic symptoms like low-grade fever; the acute immediate onset after irritant exposure points toward irritative rhinitis.

 

Option D. Bacterial rhinitis; start systemic antibiotics immediately: Incorrect. Bacterial rhinitis usually follows viral rhinitis or presents with more persistent purulent discharge; antibiotics are not first-line in irritative rhinitis unless superinfection occurs.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The severity and duration depend on the extent of epithelial damage and presence of secondary infection.
  • Prevention includes avoiding exposure and protective measures in the workplace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irritative rhinitis presents with acute sneezing and nasal symptoms immediately after exposure to irritant substances, managed primarily by removing the offending agent and supportive care.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 152

choices.text: Hypertrophic rhinitis; refer for surgical reduction of turbinates.
Chronic simple rhinitis; treat underlying causes, nasal irrigations, and avoid overuse of nasal decongestants.
Allergic rhinitis; initiate intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines.
Rhinitis medicamentosa; immediately stop all nasal sprays without tapering.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with persistent nasal obstruction worse at night, thick nasal discharge, frequent throat clearing, and headaches. Examination reveals swollen, dull red turbinates that pit on pressure and shrink after nasal decongestant application. There is postnasal mucopurulent discharge on the posterior pharyngeal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic simple rhinitis; treat underlying causes, nasal irrigations, and avoid overuse of nasal decongestants.

 

Chronic simple rhinitis presents with nasal obstruction (worse on lying down), thick mucoid or mucopurulent nasal discharge with postnasal drip, headaches, and swollen turbinates that pit on pressure and shrink with decongestants. Management involves addressing underlying causes (sinusitis, tonsillitis, allergies, smoking, environmental irritants), nasal irrigations with alkaline solutions, judicious use of nasal decongestants to avoid rebound congestion, and antibiotics if infection is present. Short courses of systemic steroids may be required in cases of rhinitis medicamentosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophic rhinitis; refer for surgical reduction of turbinates: Incorrect. In hypertrophic rhinitis, turbinates are enlarged and do not shrink with vasoconstrictors. The reversible swelling and shrinking seen here point toward chronic simple rhinitis, an early stage of hypertrophic rhinitis.

 

Option C. Allergic rhinitis; initiate intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis usually shows pale, bluish, or pale pink turbinates and is associated with itching and sneezing; the color and response to decongestants differ.

 

Option D. Rhinitis medicamentosa; immediately stop all nasal sprays without tapering: Incorrect. Rhinitis medicamentosa results from overuse of nasal sprays, but abrupt stopping can worsen symptoms; a gradual tapering often with systemic steroids is preferred.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Chronic irritation from dust, smoke, and metabolic factors can predispose to chronic simple rhinitis.
  • Nasal irrigations help clear thick secretions and reduce infections.
  • Avoiding excessive use of nasal decongestants prevents medicamentosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic simple rhinitis presents with reversible swollen turbinates and thick nasal discharge; management focuses on treating underlying causes, nasal irrigation, and cautious use of decongestants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 152

choices.text: Start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines only.
Recommend partial turbinectomy or submucosal diathermy after identifying and addressing the cause.
Advise complete removal of middle and inferior turbinates to relieve obstruction.
Prescribe prolonged use of nasal decongestant sprays to reduce turbinate size.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent nasal obstruction and thick, sticky nasal discharge. Examination reveals hypertrophied inferior turbinates that do not pit on pressure and show minimal shrinkage after vasoconstrictor application. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recommend partial turbinectomy or submucosal diathermy after identifying and addressing the cause.

 

Hypertrophic rhinitis causes thickened, fibrotic turbinates that do not respond well to vasoconstrictors. After determining and removing underlying causes (e.g., chronic infections, smoking), surgical reduction such as partial turbinectomy, submucosal diathermy, linear cauterization, or cryosurgery is indicated to relieve nasal obstruction. Submucous resection preserves mucosa and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines only: Incorrect. While intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines can help in allergic rhinitis and some inflammation, hypertrophic rhinitis involves fibrotic thickening of mucosa and submucosa, making medical therapy alone insufficient.

 

Option C. Advise complete removal of middle and inferior turbinates to relieve obstruction: Incorrect. Complete removal of turbinates is not recommended due to risk of persistent crusting and other complications. Partial removal targeting hypertrophied areas is preferred.

 

Option D. Prescribe prolonged use of nasal decongestant sprays to reduce turbinate size: Incorrect. Prolonged use of nasal decongestants can cause rhinitis medicamentosa and worsen symptoms. Minimal shrinkage with vasoconstrictors indicates fibrosis.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The inferior turbinate is most commonly involved and can have localized hypertrophy giving a mulberry appearance.
  • Etiologies include recurrent infections, chronic sinusitis, smoking, irritants, vasomotor, and allergic rhinitis.
  • Laser therapy is also a modern option for turbinate reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic rhinitis with fibrotic turbinate enlargement requires surgical turbinate reduction after addressing underlying causes, as medical therapy alone is often inadequate.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 153

choices.text: Turbinate hypertrophy on the wider side is compensatory and usually resolves after septal correction.
Compensatory turbinate hypertrophy is irreversible and requires turbinate reduction during septal surgery.
Turbinate hypertrophy indicates allergic rhinitis and responds well to intranasal steroids alone.
The widened nasal cavity causes increased airflow and improved nasal function; no further treatment is needed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with chronic nasal obstruction predominantly on the right side. Examination reveals a marked leftward deviation of the nasal septum. The right nasal cavity is wide with hypertrophied inferior and middle turbinates. After septoplasty, the nasal obstruction persists on the right side. What is the most likely explanation and appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compensatory turbinate hypertrophy is irreversible and requires turbinate reduction during septal surgery.

 

Since compensatory turbinate hypertrophy persists even after septoplasty, surgical reduction of the turbinates is often required simultaneously to relieve nasal obstruction and prevent persistent symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turbinate hypertrophy on the wider side is compensatory and usually resolves after septal correction: Incorrect. In compensatory hypertrophic rhinitis, the turbinate hypertrophy on the wider side is a physiological attempt to reduce excessive airflow and dryness. This hypertrophy is not reversible solely by correcting the deviated septum.

 

Option C. Turbinate hypertrophy indicates allergic rhinitis and responds well to intranasal steroids alone: Incorrect. Although allergic rhinitis can cause turbinate swelling, compensatory hypertrophy due to septal deviation involves fibrotic changes less responsive to medical therapy alone.

 

Option D. The widened nasal cavity causes increased airflow and improved nasal function; no further treatment is needed: Incorrect. The widened nasal cavity causes problems like drying and crusting, prompting compensatory turbinate hypertrophy to improve nasal function, so further management is often necessary.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The inferior and middle turbinates hypertrophy on the side opposite the septal deviation.
  • This hypertrophy is an adaptive mechanism but leads to persistent nasal obstruction if untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Compensatory turbinate hypertrophy caused by septal deviation is irreversible with septal correction alone and often requires simultaneous turbinate reduction surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 153

choices.text: Hereditary factors involving familial occurrence
Hormonal disturbances related to puberty and menopause
Nutritional deficiencies such as vitamin A or iron
Bacterial infection by Klebsiella pneumoniae as the initiating cause

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Examination reveals roomy nasal cavities with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates. The disease started around puberty and tends to improve after menopause. Which of the following is not considered a primary cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bacterial infection by Klebsiella pneumoniae as the initiating cause

 

While bacteria like Klebsiella ozaenae and others are often found in patients, they are considered secondary invaders that contribute to the foul smell and infection, not the primary cause of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary factors involving familial occurrence: Hereditary factors are implicated as some families have multiple affected members, indicating a genetic predisposition.

 

Option B. Hormonal disturbances related to puberty and menopause: Hormonal changes starting at puberty, with improvement after menopause, suggest an endocrinal contribution to disease development.

 

Option C. Nutritional deficiencies such as vitamin A or iron: Deficiencies in nutrients such as vitamins A and D or iron are linked to the disease, especially in populations with poor nutrition.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Racial susceptibility and autoimmune reactions triggered by viral infections may also play roles.
  • The hallmark is atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinates, leading to widened nasal cavities with foul-smelling crusts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary atrophic rhinitis involves mucosal and turbinate atrophy caused by hereditary, hormonal, nutritional, racial, and autoimmune factors; bacteria found are secondary contributors.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 153

choices.text: Preservation of ciliated columnar epithelium with hypertrophy of seromucinous glands
Replacement of ciliated columnar epithelium by stratified squamous epithelium with atrophy of seromucinous glands and obliterative endarteritis
Hyperplasia of venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements in nasal mucosa
Enlargement of turbinates causing narrowing of nasal chambers

questions.text: Which of the following pathological features is characteristic of atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replacement of ciliated columnar epithelium by stratified squamous epithelium with atrophy of seromucinous glands and obliterative endarteritis

 

The pathological hallmarks of atrophic rhinitis include loss of ciliated epithelium replaced by stratified squamous epithelium, atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids, nerve elements, and obliterative endarteritis in arteries of mucosa, periosteum, and bone. This results in resorption of turbinate bone, widening nasal chambers, and small paranasal sinuses due to arrested development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preservation of ciliated columnar epithelium with hypertrophy of seromucinous glands: Incorrect. In atrophic rhinitis, the normal ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and replaced by stratified squamous epithelium, and seromucinous glands undergo atrophy rather than hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Hyperplasia of venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements in nasal mucosa: Incorrect. Venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements undergo atrophy, not hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Enlargement of turbinates causing narrowing of nasal chambers: Incorrect. Turbinates undergo bone resorption, leading to widening of nasal chambers, not enlargement or narrowing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized pathologically by loss of ciliated epithelium replaced with stratified squamous epithelium, atrophy of seromucinous glands and vascular structures, obliterative endarteritis, and turbinate bone resorption causing widened nasal cavities.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 153

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis with nasal polyps
Atrophic rhinitis with secondary atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis
Chronic sinusitis with nasal septal deviation
Rhinitis medicamentosa

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal obstruction despite having wide nasal cavities. She complains of a foul nasal smell which she does not notice herself. On examination, the nasal cavities are filled with thick greenish-black crusts that bleed on removal. The nasal mucosa appears pale with marked atrophy of the turbinates. The posterior wall of the nasopharynx is visible. She also has hoarseness and dry, glazed pharyngeal mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis with secondary atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by wide nasal cavities filled with foul-smelling crusts, nasal mucosal atrophy, and marked anosmia (“merciful anosmia”). Bleeding occurs on crust removal. Secondary involvement of pharyngeal and laryngeal mucosa causes atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis, leading to dry throat and hoarseness. Visible posterior nasopharyngeal wall and pale mucosa are typical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis with nasal polyps: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis typically presents with pale, boggy nasal mucosa and nasal obstruction but not with foul-smelling crusts, mucosal atrophy, or wide nasal cavities. Nasal polyps are not described.

 

Option C. Chronic sinusitis with nasal septal deviation: Incorrect. Chronic sinusitis causes nasal obstruction and mucopurulent discharge but not wide nasal cavities or mucosal atrophy with crusting. Septal deviation usually causes narrowing, not widening.

 

Option D. Rhinitis medicamentosa: Incorrect. Rhinitis medicamentosa results from overuse of nasal decongestants and presents with rebound congestion but not with mucosal atrophy, crusting, or foul smell.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Septal perforation and saddle nose deformity may be present in advanced cases.
  • Paranasal sinuses are small and thick-walled, often appearing opaque on X-ray, complicating procedures like antral wash.
  • Hearing loss may occur due to Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis presents with wide nasal cavities filled with foul-smelling crusts, mucosal and turbinate atrophy, anosmia, and secondary involvement of pharynx and larynx causing hoarseness and dryness.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 154

choices.text: Nasal irrigation with warm normal saline or alkaline solution
Topical application of 25% glucose in glycerine
Submucosal injection of placental extract
Systemic use of potassium iodide

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis is started on treatment to improve nasal hygiene and reduce foul-smelling crusts. Which of the following treatment modalities is effective in inhibiting proteolytic organisms responsible for the putrid odor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical application of 25% glucose in glycerine

 

Application of 25% glucose in glycerine to the nasal mucosa inhibits the growth of proteolytic organisms responsible for the characteristic putrid odor in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal irrigation with warm normal saline or alkaline solution: Nasal irrigation with saline or alkaline solution helps to loosen and remove crusts and thick nasal discharge but does not directly inhibit proteolytic bacteria causing the foul smell.

 

Option C. Submucosal injection of placental extract: Placental extract injected submucosally may promote mucosal regeneration and provide relief but does not specifically inhibit bacterial proteolytic activity.

 

Option D. Systemic use of potassium iodide: Potassium iodide is given orally to promote and liquefy nasal secretions but does not act directly on proteolytic bacteria.

 

Additional treatment options include local antibiotics (e.g., chloromycetin-containing sprays) to eliminate secondary infections, oestradiol spray to improve mucosal vascularity and gland regeneration, and systemic streptomycin effective against Klebsiella organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrophic rhinitis, topical 25% glucose in glycerine is used to inhibit proteolytic organisms responsible for foul nasal odor.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 154

choices.text: Complete turbinectomy of inferior turbinates
Young’s operation involving complete closure of nostrils followed by delayed reopening
Nasal septoplasty to correct deviated nasal septum
Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to clear sinuses

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with severe atrophic rhinitis has persistent nasal crusting and foul odor despite medical management. Examination shows markedly widened nasal cavities contributing to mucosal drying and crust formation. Which of the following surgical procedures aims to reduce nasal airflow by narrowing the nasal cavities to alleviate symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Young’s operation involving complete closure of nostrils followed by delayed reopening

 

Young’s operation involves complete closure of both nostrils just inside the vestibule by raising flaps, temporarily eliminating airflow through the nose. This allows mucosa to recover, reduces crusting, and can improve symptoms. The modified Young’s operation partially closes nostrils to avoid total nasal obstruction but offers similar benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete turbinectomy of inferior turbinates: Incorrect. Complete turbinectomy reduces turbinate size but does not narrow the nasal airways sufficiently to prevent drying and crusting characteristic of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Option C. Nasal septoplasty to correct deviated nasal septum: Incorrect. Nasal septoplasty corrects septal deviation but does not address the wide nasal cavities or mucosal atrophy seen in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Option D. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to clear sinuses: Incorrect. FESS is performed to improve sinus drainage but is not aimed at reducing airflow or crusting in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Additional surgical methods for narrowing nasal cavities include submucosal injection of teflon paste, and insertion of fat, cartilage, bone, or teflon strips under mucoperiosteum to reduce nasal space and airflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrophic rhinitis with widened nasal cavities, Young’s operation and other nasal narrowing procedures reduce airflow to prevent mucosal drying and crusting.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 154

choices.text: Primary hereditary atrophic rhinitis with endocrine disturbances
Secondary atrophic rhinitis due to chronic infection and surgical trauma
Allergic rhinitis with hypertrophy of turbinates
Vasomotor rhinitis with recurrent nasal congestion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of long-standing purulent sinusitis and previous nasal surgery presents with nasal crusting, foul odor, and mucosal atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary atrophic rhinitis due to chronic infection and surgical trauma

 

Secondary atrophic rhinitis occurs due to specific infections such as syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma, or results from long-standing purulent sinusitis, radiotherapy, or excessive surgical removal of turbinates, causing destruction and atrophy of nasal structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary hereditary atrophic rhinitis with endocrine disturbances: Incorrect. Primary atrophic rhinitis is idiopathic and often related to hereditary, endocrine, nutritional, and autoimmune factors, typically starting around puberty.

 

Option C. Allergic rhinitis with hypertrophy of turbinates: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis causes mucosal swelling and hypertrophy but not mucosal atrophy or crusting with foul odor.

 

Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis with recurrent nasal congestion: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis causes nasal congestion and rhinorrhea but does not lead to atrophic changes or foul-smelling crusts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary atrophic rhinitis arises from specific infections, chronic sinusitis, radiotherapy, or excessive turbinate surgery leading to nasal mucosal and structural atrophy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 154

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis causing mucosal swelling on the wider side
Unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to extreme septal deviation causing mucosal atrophy on the wider nasal cavity
Primary atrophic rhinitis affecting both nasal cavities equally
Acute bacterial rhinitis secondary to sinus infection

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with chronic nasal crusting and foul-smelling discharge predominantly from the right nostril. Examination reveals a marked deviation of the nasal septum to the left side. Which of the following best explains the nasal findings on the right side?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to extreme septal deviation causing mucosal atrophy on the wider nasal cavity

 

Extreme deviation of the nasal septum results in a wider nasal cavity on the opposite side, which may develop unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to mucosal drying, crusting, and atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis causing mucosal swelling on the wider side: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis typically causes mucosal swelling and bilateral symptoms rather than crusting and foul smell localized to one side.

 

Option C. Primary atrophic rhinitis affecting both nasal cavities equally: Incorrect. Primary atrophic rhinitis is generally bilateral and idiopathic rather than limited to one nasal cavity.

 

Option D. Acute bacterial rhinitis secondary to sinus infection: Incorrect. Acute bacterial rhinitis presents with mucopurulent discharge and inflammation but does not cause the characteristic crusting and mucosal atrophy seen in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The wider nasal cavity causes drying and crust formation due to increased airflow and loss of mucosal integrity.
  • Management includes treating the atrophic changes and possibly correcting the septal deviation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extreme nasal septal deviation causes widening of the contralateral nasal cavity, leading to unilateral atrophic rhinitis characterized by mucosal atrophy and crusting.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 155

choices.text: Frequent forceful removal of crusts to prevent infection
Correction of occupational exposure and application of bland ointment or antibiotic-steroid ointment
Systemic corticosteroids and nasal packing
Surgical removal of affected septal mucosa

questions.text: A 40-year-old baker presents with crusting and ulceration on the anterior part of his nasal septum, associated with occasional nosebleeds. Examination reveals squamous metaplasia of the nasal mucosa and atrophy of seromucinous glands confined to the anterior third of the nose. What is the most appropriate management for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Correction of occupational exposure and application of bland ointment or antibiotic-steroid ointment

 

Rhinitis sicca affects workers in hot, dry, dusty environments (e.g., bakers), causing squamous metaplasia and atrophy of glands with crust formation primarily on the anterior nasal septum. Management includes improving occupational conditions and applying bland ointments or antibiotic-steroid ointments to promote healing. Nasal douching can also be helpful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frequent forceful removal of crusts to prevent infection: Incorrect. Forceful removal of crusts causes ulceration, epistaxis, and may lead to septal perforation; it should be avoided.

 

Option C. Systemic corticosteroids and nasal packing: Incorrect. Systemic corticosteroids are not indicated; nasal packing is unnecessary and may worsen symptoms.

 

Option D. Surgical removal of affected septal mucosa: Incorrect. Surgery is not the first-line treatment and is reserved for complicated cases; the primary management is conservative.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Crusting and mucosal changes are limited to the anterior third of the nose.
  • Ulceration and epistaxis may result from crust removal.
  • Nasal douche similar to that used in atrophic rhinitis aids in clearing crusts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinitis sicca involves crusting and mucosal atrophy in the anterior nasal septum due to occupational exposure and is managed by improving environment and applying ointments while avoiding forceful crust removal.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 155

choices.text: Systemic antibiotics and nasal corticosteroids
Surgical removal of debris and granulation tissue with free drainage of the sinus
Radiotherapy for suspected malignancy
Conservative management with nasal irrigation only

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling purulent discharge mixed with cheesy material from the nose. Imaging reveals destruction of the bony walls of the affected sinus. Histopathology shows granulomatous inflammation of the sinus mucosa. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical removal of debris and granulation tissue with free drainage of the sinus

 

Rhinitis caseosa is characterized by unilateral accumulation of offensive purulent and cheesy material due to chronic sinusitis. Granulomatous sinus mucosa and bony destruction may mimic malignancy. Treatment involves surgical removal of debris and granulation tissue and ensuring free drainage of the affected sinus. Prognosis is generally good with surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic antibiotics and nasal corticosteroids: Incorrect. While antibiotics may help infection control, systemic antibiotics alone are insufficient due to the presence of inspissated cheesy material and granulomatous inflammation.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy for suspected malignancy: Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not indicated unless malignancy is confirmed; rhinitis caseosa can mimic malignancy but is a benign inflammatory condition.

 

Option D. Conservative management with nasal irrigation only: Incorrect. Conservative management alone is inadequate due to the dense material and bony destruction; surgical intervention is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinitis caseosa is a unilateral granulomatous sinusitis with cheesy nasal discharge requiring surgical removal of debris and drainage for effective treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 155

choices.text: Connecticut Chemosensory Clinical Research Center test (CCCRC)
Sniffin’ Sticks test
University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
Baseline Smell Test 24 odors (BAST-24)

questions.text: Which of the following smell identification tests uses 40 encapsulated odors in a scratch-and-sniff technique, has a duration of about 15 minutes, and includes scoring reference values adjusted for age and gender?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)

 

UPSIT, validated in the USA, uses 40 encapsulated odors with a scratch-and-sniff technique, takes approximately 15 minutes, and scoring is based on reference values adjusted for age and gender. Test-retest reliability is very high (r = 0.981).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Connecticut Chemosensory Clinical Research Center test (CCCRC): The CCCRC test uses 10 odors in a pen sniffing technique, lasts about 35 minutes, and involves threshold assessment using increasing dilutions of n-butanol.

 

Option B. Sniffin’ Sticks test: Sniffin’ Sticks test from Germany uses 16 odors in pens with a duration of about 25 minutes and defines normalcy based on forced choice identification accuracy >75%.

 

Option D. Baseline Smell Test 24 odors (BAST-24): BAST-24 from Spain includes 24 odors with a scentoid stick sniffing technique, lasting 20 minutes, and scores are adjusted for age, gender, and smoking habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a rapid, standardized 40-odor scratch-and-sniff test with age- and gender-specific normative scoring widely used for olfactory function assessment.

 

Ref: Adapted from the comparative data on olfactory tests — UPSIT, CCCRC, Sniffin’ Sticks, Small Disks test, and BAST-24.

choices.text: Continue nasal decongestant sprays but increase the dose gradually
Discontinue nasal decongestants and start short course of systemic and local steroids
Switch to oral antihistamines for better control of nasal symptoms
Perform surgical reduction of nasal turbinates

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with persistent nasal congestion despite using over-the-counter nasal sprays several times daily for the past two months. He reports that the sprays provide temporary relief but the congestion worsens when he stops them. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue nasal decongestants and start short course of systemic and local steroids

 

The treatment of rhinitis medicamentosa involves stopping the nasal decongestant sprays and administering a short course of systemic and topical steroids to reduce inflammation and aid recovery of nasal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue nasal decongestant sprays but increase the dose gradually: Incorrect. Prolonged use of nasal decongestants causes rhinitis medicamentosa, a rebound nasal congestion due to downregulation of alpha-adrenergic receptors, worsening symptoms despite increasing doses. Continuing or increasing the dose will exacerbate the problem.

 

Option C. Switch to oral antihistamines for better control of nasal symptoms: Incorrect. Oral antihistamines do not address the underlying receptor downregulation and are ineffective for rhinitis medicamentosa.

 

Option D. Perform surgical reduction of nasal turbinates: Incorrect. Surgery is not indicated for rhinitis medicamentosa and is reserved for structural causes of nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinitis medicamentosa caused by prolonged nasal decongestant use requires discontinuation of the drug and short-term steroid therapy to restore nasal mucosal function.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168,183

choices.text: Intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines only
Nasal irrigation with alkaline solution, topical 25% glucose in glycerine, and systemic streptomycin
Immediate surgical removal of turbinates to reduce nasal cavity size
Oral antibiotics alone without local treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal crusting, foul-smelling discharge, and nasal obstruction despite wide nasal cavities. She has anosmia and the nasal mucosa appears pale. Biopsy shows stratified squamous epithelium replacing normal ciliated columnar epithelium, and imaging reveals turbinate bone resorption. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal irrigation with alkaline solution, topical 25% glucose in glycerine, and systemic streptomycin

 

Treatment includes nasal irrigation with alkaline solution (sodium biborate, sodium bicarbonate, sodium chloride mix) to remove crusts, 25% glucose in glycerine to inhibit proteolytic bacteria, and systemic streptomycin targeting Klebsiella ozaenae, a common secondary infective organism. Topical agents like Kemicetine antiozaena (chloromycetin, oestradiol, vitamin D2) and oestradiol spray help improve vascularity and mucosal health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines only: Incorrect. Medical management in atrophic rhinitis requires more than corticosteroids and antihistamines; addressing crust removal, infection control, and mucosal regeneration is essential.

 

Option C. Immediate surgical removal of turbinates to reduce nasal cavity size: Incorrect. Surgical reduction of turbinates is not first-line and is reserved for selected cases; indiscriminate removal can worsen symptoms.

 

Option D. Oral antibiotics alone without local treatment: Incorrect. Oral antibiotics alone without local treatment and crust management are insufficient to control symptoms and prevent progression.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Anosmia in atrophic rhinitis is due to atrophy of nerve elements ("merciful anosmia").
  • Mucosal atrophy and obliterative endarteritis cause pale mucosa and turbinate bone resorption leading to widened nasal cavities.
  • Surgical options include Young’s operation (complete nostril closure), modified Young’s (partial closure), and Lautenslager’s operation (narrowing nasal lumen with submucosal implants or medial displacement).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis requires combined medical management with nasal irrigation, topical antiseptics, systemic antibiotics, and possibly surgical intervention to control crusting, infection, and nasal airflow.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis
Viral upper respiratory infection
Drug-induced rhinitis due to oral contraceptive pills
Bacterial sinusitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of persistent nasal congestion and watery nasal discharge. She denies any history of allergies or recent infections. She recently started taking oral contraceptive pills for birth control. Physical examination reveals swollen nasal mucosa without signs of infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug-induced rhinitis due to oral contraceptive pills

 

  • Drug-induced rhinitis is a known adverse effect of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) containing estrogen. Estrogen can cause mucosal edema and increased nasal secretions leading to rhinitis symptoms without allergy or infection.
  • Allergic rhinitis typically presents with sneezing, itching, and a history of allergies, which are absent here.
  • Viral upper respiratory infection usually has systemic symptoms like fever, sore throat, and resolves within 7-10 days, unlike this persistent symptom.
  • Bacterial sinusitis generally presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pain, and fever, which are not present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Usually has itching, sneezing, and a history of allergen exposure.

 

Option B. Viral upper respiratory infection: Acute, self-limiting illness with systemic signs.

 

Option D. Bacterial sinusitis: Characterized by purulent nasal discharge and facial tenderness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills can cause drug-induced rhinitis, presenting as persistent nasal congestion and rhinorrhea without allergic or infectious features.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168

choices.text: Infective rhinitis
Allergic rhinitis
Vasomotor rhinitis
Drug-induced rhinitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, sneezing, and itching inside her nose. She also reports itching in her eyes, palate, and throat. Her symptoms worsen during certain months of the year but sometimes persist throughout the year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic rhinitis

 

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunologic response of the nasal mucosa to airborne allergens. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, sneezing, and nasal itching. It is also commonly associated with itching of the eyes, palate, and pharynx. 

 

Two clinical types are recognized:

 

  1. Seasonal allergic rhinitis: Symptoms appear around particular seasons when specific pollen allergens are present.
  2. Perennial allergic rhinitis: Symptoms persist throughout the year due to year-round allergens like dust mites or pet dander.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infective rhinitis: Incorrect. Infective rhinitis typically presents with purulent nasal discharge, fever, and systemic symptoms, unlike this patient’s symptoms.

 

Option C. Vasomotor rhinitis: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-allergic condition triggered by irritants and autonomic dysfunction, lacking an IgE-mediated response.

 

Option D. Drug-induced rhinitis: Incorrect. Drug-induced rhinitis is caused by certain medications and does not present with seasonal or perennial patterns related to airborne allergens.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Allergic rhinitis involves an immunologic IgE-mediated reaction to airborne allergens.
  • Symptoms include watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, sneezing, nasal itching, and associated itching of eyes, palate, and pharynx.
  • Seasonal type is related to pollens present during specific seasons.
  • Perennial type is present year-round due to constant exposure to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunologic response of the nasal mucosa to airborne allergens, characterized by watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, sneezing, and nasal itching, with seasonal and perennial clinical types.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 166

choices.text: Seasonal allergens such as molds and dust mites are responsible for his symptoms
Genetic predisposition does not influence the development of allergic rhinitis
Dust mites are perennial allergens found in bedding and upholstery, contributing to year-round symptoms
The geographical knowledge of animal dander is irrelevant in managing allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of sneezing, nasal congestion, and watery nasal discharge that occur mostly during spring and autumn. His mother has a history of allergic rhinitis. Skin prick testing reveals sensitivity to pollen and dust mites. Which of the following statements regarding his condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dust mites are perennial allergens found in bedding and upholstery, contributing to year-round symptoms

 

Dust mites are perennial inhalant allergens found in beddings, mattresses, pillows, carpets, and upholstery. They live on skin scales and debris, causing year-round symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal allergens such as molds and dust mites are responsible for his symptoms: Incorrect. Seasonal allergens primarily include pollens from trees, grasses, and weeds, not molds and dust mites. Molds and dust mites are perennial allergens present throughout the year.

 

Option B. Genetic predisposition does not influence the development of allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. Genetic predisposition plays an important role in allergic rhinitis; children have a 20% chance of developing allergy if one parent and 47% if both parents have allergic diathesis.

 

Option D. The geographical knowledge of animal dander is irrelevant in managing allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. Knowledge of geographical and seasonal variation in pollen presence is important for diagnosis and management, including skin testing. Animal dander is also a perennial allergen relevant to management.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Allergic rhinitis involves sensitization to inhalant allergens which may be seasonal or perennial.
  • Seasonal allergens include pollens that vary geographically and seasonally.
  • Perennial allergens include molds, dust mites, cockroaches, and animal dander, which cause symptoms throughout the year.
  • Dust mites thrive on skin scales and are commonly found in household items like bedding and upholstery.
  • Family history increases risk due to genetic predisposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis results from sensitization to seasonal (pollens) and perennial (dust mites, molds, animal dander) inhalant allergens, with genetic predisposition significantly increasing the risk.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 166

choices.text: Immediate IgG-mediated reaction with neutrophil infiltration causing symptoms within 5–30 minutes
IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation causing early symptoms and a late phase inflammatory response involving eosinophils and T cells
Delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction causing symptoms 2–8 hours after exposure
Non-immunologic nasal hyper-reactivity to nonspecific irritants causing both early and late symptoms

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of allergic rhinitis experiences sneezing, nasal congestion, and watery nasal discharge within minutes of exposure to pollen. Several hours later, he develops worsening nasal blockage and thick nasal secretions without further allergen exposure. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation causing early symptoms and a late phase inflammatory response involving eosinophils and T cells

 

In genetically predisposed individuals, inhaled allergens induce specific IgE production. IgE binds to mast cells and basophils, and upon re-exposure, allergen cross-links IgE causing mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other mediators producing acute symptoms within 5–30 minutes (early phase). The late phase (2–8 hours later) results from infiltration by eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells causing sustained inflammation, swelling, congestion, and thick nasal secretions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate IgG-mediated reaction with neutrophil infiltration causing symptoms within 5–30 minutes: Incorrect. The allergic response in allergic rhinitis is IgE-mediated, not IgG-mediated, and early symptoms occur due to mast cell degranulation releasing vasoactive mediators, not primarily neutrophils.

 

 

Option C. Delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction causing symptoms 2–8 hours after exposure: Incorrect. Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed T-cell mediated reaction but allergic rhinitis primarily involves IgE-mediated immediate and late phases.

 

Option D. Non-immunologic nasal hyper-reactivity to nonspecific irritants causing both early and late symptoms: Incorrect. Although nonspecific nasal hyper-reactivity can contribute to symptoms, the initial and main pathogenesis involves IgE and mast cell-mediated immune mechanisms.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Mast cell degranulation releases preformed and newly synthesized mediators causing vasodilation, mucosal edema, glandular secretion, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • A priming effect occurs, making mucosa hyper-responsive to allergens and even nonspecific stimuli.
  • Early phase manifests as sneezing, rhinorrhea, and nasal obstruction within minutes.
  • Late phase involves inflammatory cell infiltration leading to prolonged symptoms without further allergen exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis symptoms result from an IgE-mediated immediate phase due to mast cell degranulation and a late inflammatory phase involving eosinophils and T cells, causing acute and delayed symptoms respectively.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 167

choices.text: Chronic sinusitis
Allergic rhinitis
Infective rhinitis
Vasomotor rhinitis

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of sneezing spells occurring 10–20 times at a time, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and nasal itching, especially during spring. On examination, there is a transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose and pale, swollen nasal mucosa. His eyes show dark circles under the lids and cobblestone appearance of the conjunctiva. He also reports occasional hoarseness and a chronic cough. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic rhinitis

 

Allergic rhinitis commonly starts between 12–16 years and presents with cardinal symptoms of paroxysmal sneezing (10–20 sneezes), nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching. Nasal signs include the allergic salute (transverse nasal crease), pale and oedematous mucosa, and swollen turbinates. Ocular signs include allergic shiners and conjunctival changes. Otologic signs can include retracted tympanic membrane or serous otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage. Pharyngeal signs include granular pharyngitis, and laryngeal signs include hoarseness and vocal cord oedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic sinusitis: Incorrect. Chronic sinusitis typically presents with facial pain, purulent nasal discharge, and anosmia, rather than paroxysmal sneezing and itching.

 

Option C. Infective rhinitis: Incorrect. Infective rhinitis usually presents with purulent discharge and systemic symptoms like fever, which are absent here.

 

Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-allergic condition without the immunologic features and ocular and nasal signs described.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Allergic rhinitis affects all age groups but usually begins in adolescence.
  • Seasonal allergy symptoms are more severe and vary with season, while perennial allergy presents with milder but persistent symptoms including chronic cough and hearing impairment.
  • Examination findings may involve multiple sites including nose, eyes, ears, pharynx, and larynx.
  • The allergic salute and allergic shiners are classic physical signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis typically presents with paroxysmal sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery discharge, itching, and characteristic signs including allergic salute, allergic shiners, and involvement of eyes, ears, pharynx, and larynx.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 167

choices.text: Intermittent mild
Persistent moderate to severe
Intermittent moderate to severe
Persistent mild

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with nasal congestion, sneezing, and itching for the past 6 weeks. She reports symptoms occurring daily, disturbing her sleep and impairing her work performance. According to the ARIA classification, how would her allergic rhinitis be categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Persistent moderate to severe

 

Persistent symptoms occur more than 4 days a week and for more than 4 weeks. The presence of sleep disturbance and impairment of daily activities indicates moderate to severe severity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermittent mild: Incorrect. Intermittent symptoms last less than 4 days per week or less than 4 weeks total. This patient has daily symptoms for 6 weeks, which is persistent.

 

Option C. Intermittent moderate to severe: Incorrect. Intermittent refers to symptoms lasting less than 4 days a week or under 4 weeks. This patient’s symptoms are persistent.

 

Option D. Persistent mild: Incorrect. Although symptoms are persistent, the presence of sleep disturbance and work impairment indicate moderate to severe severity, not mild.

 

Additional Points:

 

  • ARIA classification divides allergic rhinitis by duration:
    • Intermittent: symptoms <4 days/week or <4 weeks.
    • Persistent: symptoms >4 days/week and >4 weeks.
  • And by severity:
    • Mild: no sleep disturbance, no impairment of activities, work, or leisure.
    • Moderate to severe: presence of one or more impairments or troublesome symptoms.
  • This classification guides treatment decisions and prognosis.
  • Detailed history and physical exam help exclude other causes of nasal obstruction and identify allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ARIA classification categorizes allergic rhinitis based on symptom duration (intermittent or persistent) and severity (mild or moderate to severe), helping guide treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168

choices.text: Peripheral blood eosinophil count
Skin prick test
Radioallergosorbent test (RAST)
Nasal smear for eosinophils

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of seasonal nasal allergy undergoes evaluation to identify her specific allergen. She has no peripheral eosinophilia. Which of the following investigations is the best initial test to identify the allergen in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin prick test

 

Skin prick test is an excellent and widely used method to identify specific allergens. It involves placing drops of allergen solution on the skin and pricking the dermis. A positive test produces a wheal and flare reaction within 10–15 minutes, correlating well with clinical allergy. Controls with histamine and diluent validate the test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peripheral blood eosinophil count: Incorrect. Peripheral eosinophilia may be seen in allergic rhinitis but is inconsistent and nonspecific; it is not reliable for allergen identification.

 

Option C. Radioallergosorbent test (RAST): Incorrect. RAST measures specific IgE in vitro and is useful when skin tests are contraindicated or not feasible but is more expensive and less widely available. False positives and negatives may occur, so correlation with clinical history is essential.

 

Option D. Nasal smear for eosinophils: Incorrect. Nasal smear shows eosinophils during active disease but does not identify specific allergens. It is helpful for diagnosis but not for allergen identification.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Nasal smear eosinophilia can be present in allergic rhinitis and some nonallergic rhinitis (e.g., NARES).
  • Specific IgE measurements complement skin tests but require clinical correlation due to possible false results.
  • Nasal provocation tests reproduce symptoms by allergen challenge but are mostly used in research or specialized centers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The skin prick test is the best initial investigation to identify specific allergens in allergic rhinitis, showing rapid wheal and flare reaction correlating with clinical symptoms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168

choices.text: Recurrent sinusitis due to obstruction of sinus ostia
Formation of nasal polyps in approximately 2% of patients
Serous otitis media resulting from eustachian tube dysfunction
Development of vocal cord nodules

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a history of allergic rhinitis presents with persistent nasal obstruction and chronic cough. Examination reveals nasal polyps and retracted tympanic membranes bilaterally. Which of the following complications is LEAST likely to be caused by his underlying nasal allergy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Development of vocal cord nodules

 

Vocal cord nodules are typically caused by vocal abuse or misuse and are not a recognized complication of nasal allergy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent sinusitis due to obstruction of sinus ostia: Incorrect. Recurrent sinusitis is a common complication of nasal allergy caused by obstruction of sinus ostia from mucosal edema and secretions.

 

Option B. Formation of nasal polyps in approximately 2% of patients: Incorrect. Nasal polyps develop in about 2% of patients with nasal allergy due to chronic inflammation and mucosal changes.

 

Option C. Serous otitis media resulting from eustachian tube dysfunction: Incorrect. Serous otitis media occurs due to eustachian tube dysfunction and blockage caused by allergic inflammation of the nasal mucosa.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Prolonged mouth breathing due to nasal obstruction may cause orthodontic problems and facial growth abnormalities, especially in children.
  • Patients with nasal allergy have a significantly increased risk (fourfold) of developing bronchial asthma; 20–30% of rhinitis patients have asthma.
  • Managing nasal allergy is important to prevent these complications and improve quality of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal allergy can cause recurrent sinusitis, nasal polyps, serous otitis media, orthodontic issues from mouth breathing, and increases risk of bronchial asthma, but it is not associated with vocal cord nodules.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 169

choices.text: Start oral antihistamines immediately
Advise removal of the cat from the environment and encase bedding with plastic covers
Begin intranasal corticosteroids without environmental changes
Prescribe systemic corticosteroids for symptom relief

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with allergic rhinitis experiences worsening nasal congestion and sneezing whenever she visits her friend’s house, which has a cat. Skin prick testing confirms sensitivity to cat dander. Which of the following is the most effective initial step in managing her allergic symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Advise removal of the cat from the environment and encase bedding with plastic covers

 

Avoidance of the specific allergen, such as removing the pet and encasing pillows or mattresses with plastic covers, is the most successful approach to managing allergic rhinitis when the antigen involved is singular and identifiable.
