Changes in workplace or even job may sometimes be necessary for severe sensitivities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral antihistamines immediately: Incorrect. Oral antihistamines are effective symptomatic treatment but allergen avoidance is the primary and most successful management, especially if a single allergen is identified.

 

Option C. Begin intranasal corticosteroids without environmental changes: Incorrect. Intranasal corticosteroids are useful but should ideally be combined with allergen avoidance for maximal efficacy.

 

Option D. Prescribe systemic corticosteroids for symptom relief: Incorrect. Systemic corticosteroids have significant side effects and are reserved for severe or refractory cases, not as first-line treatment.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Identifying and eliminating food allergens from the diet may also be necessary if food allergy is demonstrated.
  • Allergen avoidance helps reduce symptoms and the need for medications.
  • Patient education about environmental controls is critical for long-term management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cornerstone of allergic rhinitis management is avoidance of the specific allergen, including environmental modifications like removing pets and encasing bedding, especially when a single antigen is involved.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 169

choices.text: Increase the dose of topical nasal decongestants
Start topical corticosteroid nasal spray and gradually withdraw decongestant drops
Begin oral corticosteroids for long-term control
Add leukotriene receptor antagonists as first-line therapy

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with perennial allergic rhinitis is treated with oral antihistamines and topical nasal decongestants for nasal congestion and rhinorrhea. After several weeks, he develops worsening nasal obstruction despite increasing use of nasal drops. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start topical corticosteroid nasal spray and gradually withdraw decongestant drops

 

Topical corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, budesonide) reduce nasal mucosal inflammation, suppress late-phase allergic responses, and are effective in controlling symptoms. They are used to treat rhinitis medicamentosa by helping withdrawal from topical decongestants while preventing rebound congestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of topical nasal decongestants: Incorrect. Increasing topical nasal decongestants will worsen rebound congestion and perpetuate rhinitis medicamentosa, a vicious cycle of nasal obstruction due to overuse of decongestants.

 

Option C. Begin oral corticosteroids for long-term control: Incorrect. Oral corticosteroids are effective but should be reserved for acute severe episodes due to systemic side effects; not recommended for long-term control.

 

Option D. Add leukotriene receptor antagonists as first-line therapy: Incorrect. Leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast) can be used as adjunct therapy but are not first-line treatments, especially in cases complicated by rhinitis medicamentosa.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Antihistaminics control rhinorrhea, sneezing, and itching but may cause drowsiness.
  • Sympathomimetic decongestants (pseudoephedrine, oxymetazoline) reduce congestion but risk rebound congestion and rhinitis medicamentosa on prolonged use.
  • Sodium cromoglycate stabilizes mast cells, preventing degranulation, useful in seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis.
  • Anticholinergic nasal sprays like ipratropium bromide effectively reduce rhinorrhea with minimal systemic side effects.
  • Anti-IgE therapy (omalizumab) is approved for asthma but not yet for allergic rhinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In allergic rhinitis complicated by rhinitis medicamentosa due to overuse of topical decongestants, topical corticosteroids are the treatment of choice to reduce inflammation and facilitate withdrawal of decongestants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 169

choices.text: Increase dose of oral antihistamines
Begin allergen immunotherapy with gradually increasing doses
Prescribe long-term oral corticosteroids
Start leukotriene receptor antagonists

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with severe allergic rhinitis has persistent symptoms despite optimal pharmacologic treatment and reports intolerable side effects from antihistamines. His allergen-specific IgE is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin allergen immunotherapy with gradually increasing doses

 

Immunotherapy (hyposensitization) is indicated when drug treatment fails or causes intolerable side effects. It involves administering gradually increasing doses of allergen to suppress IgE formation and increase specific IgG antibodies. Subcutaneous immunotherapy is common, with sublingual and nasal routes also available using higher doses. It requires at least 1 year for significant improvement and may continue up to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of oral antihistamines: Incorrect. Increasing antihistamine dose may worsen side effects and is unlikely to control severe symptoms that are refractory to standard treatment.

 

Option C. Prescribe long-term oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Long-term oral corticosteroids have significant systemic side effects and are not recommended for chronic allergic rhinitis management.

 

Option D. Start leukotriene receptor antagonists: Incorrect. Leukotriene receptor antagonists can be adjunctive therapy but are not indicated as primary treatment after drug failure in severe allergic rhinitis.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Immunotherapy modifies the immune response by reducing IgE and increasing blocking IgG antibodies.
  • Sublingual and nasal immunotherapy are newer methods allowing higher allergen doses.
  • Treatment is discontinued if no clinical improvement after 3 years of uninterrupted therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergen immunotherapy with gradually increasing doses is indicated in allergic rhinitis patients unresponsive or intolerant to pharmacologic therapy and works by modulating IgE and IgG antibody responses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 169

choices.text: Continue oral antihistamines alone and add oral corticosteroids
Start intranasal corticosteroids as monotherapy
Prescribe intranasal decongestants alone for prolonged use
Begin allergen immunotherapy immediately

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with persistent allergic rhinitis reports moderate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and itching despite using oral antihistamines intermittently. According to ARIA guidelines, what is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start intranasal corticosteroids as monotherapy

 

For moderate severity or persistent allergic rhinitis, intranasal corticosteroids as monotherapy are recommended to reduce inflammation and symptoms effectively.

 

ARIA Step-Care Approach for Allergic Rhinitis Treatment

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue oral antihistamines alone and add oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Oral antihistamines alone are recommended for mild intermittent disease. Oral corticosteroids are reserved for severe and persistent symptoms not controlled by other measures.

 

Option C. Prescribe intranasal decongestants alone for prolonged use: Incorrect. Intranasal decongestants are useful only for short-term relief of nasal obstruction due to the risk of rhinitis medicamentosa and rebound congestion with prolonged use.

 

Option D. Begin allergen immunotherapy immediately: Incorrect. Immunotherapy is reserved for severe, persistent symptoms unresponsive to pharmacologic treatment, not the initial step for moderate persistent disease.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Mild intermittent symptoms are managed with oral antihistamines or intranasal cromolyn sodium.
  • Severe symptoms require combination therapy with oral nonsedating antihistamines and intranasal steroids.
  • Avoidance of allergens and irritants is essential across all disease severities.
  • Nonallergic rhinitis may coexist with allergic rhinitis, leading to nasal hyper-reactivity and rhinitis-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to ARIA guidelines, intranasal corticosteroids are the preferred monotherapy for moderate or persistent allergic rhinitis not controlled by antihistamines.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 169

choices.text: Oral corticosteroids
Avoidance of allergens and oral antihistamines
Surgical removal of nasal turbinates
Antibiotic therapy

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent sneezing spells (10–20 sneezes at a time), watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, and nasal itching. On examination, a transverse nasal crease and dark circles under the eyes are noted. Her family history is positive for allergies. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum IgE and absolute eosinophil count. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Avoidance of allergens and oral antihistamines

 

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction characterized by symptoms like sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching. Initial management focuses on allergen avoidance and symptomatic relief with oral antihistamines (e.g., levocetirizine). Additional treatments include topical steroids, mast cell stabilizers, leukotriene receptor antagonists, and monoclonal antibodies for severe cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Oral corticosteroids are reserved for severe or refractory cases due to their systemic side effects and are not first-line therapy.

 

Option C. Surgical removal of nasal turbinates: Incorrect. Surgery is not indicated in allergic rhinitis unless complicated by structural problems or nasal polyps unresponsive to medical treatment.

 

Option D. Antibiotic therapy: Incorrect. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a secondary bacterial infection.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Clinical signs like allergic salute (transverse nasal crease) and allergic shiners are characteristic.
  • Laboratory findings include elevated absolute eosinophil count and serum IgE measured by RAST.
  • Treatment aims at controlling symptoms and preventing complications through pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic means.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis is a type I IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction managed initially with allergen avoidance and oral antihistamines to relieve symptoms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 168

choices.text: IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction with eosinophilic infiltration
Overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system causing mucosal vasodilation and glandular hypersecretion
Chronic bacterial infection causing mucosal inflammation
Structural nasal deformity causing turbulent airflow and irritation

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with persistent nasal obstruction, clear rhinorrhea, and occasional sneezing throughout the year. Allergy testing including skin prick tests and serum IgE are negative. Symptoms worsen with changes in temperature, humidity, and exposure to smoke. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system causing mucosal vasodilation and glandular hypersecretion

 

Vasomotor rhinitis is a nonallergic condition characterized by autonomic nervous system imbalance, with overactive parasympathetic stimulation leading to vasodilation of nasal mucosa and excessive glandular secretions. The nasal mucosa is hyper-reactive to nonspecific stimuli like temperature changes, humidity, dust, and smoke. Emotional factors mediated via hypothalamus also influence symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction with eosinophilic infiltration: Incorrect. IgE-mediated hypersensitivity causes allergic rhinitis; negative allergy tests rule this out.

 

Option C. Chronic bacterial infection causing mucosal inflammation: Incorrect. Chronic bacterial infection causes infective rhinitis, which presents differently with purulent discharge and systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Structural nasal deformity causing turbulent airflow and irritation: Incorrect. Structural abnormalities may cause obstruction but do not explain persistent rhinorrhea and sneezing with negative allergy tests and hyper-reactive nasal mucosa.

 

Additional points:

 

  • VMR symptoms persist year-round and mimic allergic rhinitis but without immunologic basis.
  • The nasal mucosa has venous sinusoids regulated by sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers controlling congestion and secretions.
  • Autonomic instability and hypersensitivity to nonspecific environmental triggers characterize VMR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vasomotor rhinitis is a nonallergic condition caused by parasympathetic overactivity and nasal mucosal hyper-reactivity to nonspecific stimuli, leading to persistent nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea despite negative allergy tests.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 170

choices.text: Nasal septal perforation
Nasal polyps and hypertrophic rhinitis
Deviated nasal septum
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complains of sudden bouts of sneezing immediately after waking up, profuse watery nasal discharge, and nasal obstruction that alternates between the two sides, especially worse at night. On examination, his nasal mucosa appears congested and hypertrophic over the turbinates. Which of the following complications is most likely to develop if this condition persists untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal polyps and hypertrophic rhinitis

 

Long-standing vasomotor rhinitis can lead to complications such as nasal polyps, hypertrophic rhinitis, and chronic sinusitis due to persistent mucosal congestion and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal septal perforation: Incorrect. Nasal septal perforation is more commonly caused by trauma, surgery, or drug abuse, not vasomotor rhinitis.

 

Option C. Deviated nasal septum: Incorrect. Deviated nasal septum is a structural deformity and unrelated to vasomotor rhinitis.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Incorrect. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignancy and not a complication of vasomotor rhinitis.

 

Additional points:

 

  • VMR symptoms include paroxysmal sneezing, especially in the morning, excessive profuse watery rhinorrhea, alternating nasal obstruction worse at night, and postnasal drip.
  • Nasal mucosa may appear congested and hypertrophic but can be normal in some patients.
  • Differentiation of watery rhinorrhea from CSF leak is important in clinical practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vasomotor rhinitis presents with paroxysmal sneezing, profuse watery rhinorrhea, and alternating nasal obstruction, and if untreated, may lead to nasal polyps, hypertrophic rhinitis, and sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 170

choices.text: Start systemic corticosteroids for long-term use
Prescribe topical intranasal corticosteroids and advise avoidance of triggers
Recommend surgical removal of nasal turbinates
Initiate antibiotic therapy for presumed infection

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with vasomotor rhinitis experiences persistent nasal obstruction, sneezing, and watery nasal discharge triggered by sudden temperature changes and exposure to dust. She reports worsening symptoms despite antihistamines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prescribe topical intranasal corticosteroids and advise avoidance of triggers

 

Treatment of vasomotor rhinitis includes avoidance of physical triggers such as temperature changes and dust, use of topical intranasal corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, budesonide, fluticasone) to control symptoms, and antihistamines or oral decongestants for symptomatic relief. Psychological factors may also contribute and tranquillizers can be considered if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start systemic corticosteroids for long-term use: Incorrect. Systemic corticosteroids are reserved for short-term use in very severe cases due to their systemic side effects and are not recommended for long-term management.

 

Option C. Recommend surgical removal of nasal turbinates: Incorrect. Surgery is not indicated as first-line treatment for vasomotor rhinitis.

 

Option D. Initiate antibiotic therapy for presumed infection: Incorrect. Antibiotics have no role unless there is a documented secondary infection, which is not typical in VMR.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Avoidance of triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, dust, and air blasts is critical.
  • Antihistamines and oral nasal decongestants help relieve sneezing, obstruction, and rhinorrhea.
  • Psychological factors can worsen symptoms; addressing these may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mainstay of vasomotor rhinitis treatment is avoidance of triggers combined with topical intranasal corticosteroids and symptomatic relief using antihistamines and decongestants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Septoplasty alone
Reduction of nasal turbinates and correction of deviated septum
Vidian neurectomy to section parasympathetic secretomotor fibers
Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with refractory vasomotor rhinitis presents with persistent nasal obstruction and profuse rhinorrhea despite maximal medical therapy. Nasal examination reveals hypertrophied turbinates and a deviated nasal septum. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management to control his excessive rhinorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vidian neurectomy to section parasympathetic secretomotor fibers

 

Vidian neurectomy involves cutting parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the nose, effectively reducing excessive rhinorrhea in patients unresponsive to medical treatment. It is reserved for severe, bothersome rhinorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty alone: Incorrect. Septoplasty alone corrects structural deviation but does not reduce rhinorrhea or turbinate size.

 

Option B. Reduction of nasal turbinates and correction of deviated septum: Incorrect. Reduction of hypertrophied turbinates and correction of septal deviation relieve nasal obstruction but do not directly address excessive rhinorrhea.

 

Option D. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS): Incorrect. FESS is primarily used to treat sinus disease, not vasomotor rhinitis or nasal hypersecretion.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Surgical interventions for vasomotor rhinitis target symptom relief when medical therapy fails.
  • Addressing all causes of nasal obstruction (e.g., turbinate hypertrophy, septal deviation, nasal polyps) is important for airflow improvement.
  • Vidian neurectomy selectively reduces parasympathetic-driven nasal secretions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In vasomotor rhinitis refractory to medical treatment, vidian neurectomy is an effective surgical option to reduce excessive rhinorrhea by interrupting parasympathetic secretomotor innervation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Oral antihistamines including newer agents
Oral corticosteroids
Limited use of topical nasal decongestant drops and topical corticosteroids
Surgical removal of nasal turbinates

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy complains of persistent nasal congestion and difficulty breathing through her nose. Examination reveals oedematous nasal mucosa causing airway obstruction. Which of the following is the safest and most appropriate initial management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Limited use of topical nasal decongestant drops and topical corticosteroids

 

Rhinitis of pregnancy is due to hormonal changes causing nasal mucosal edema. Initial management includes local measures such as limited use of nasal drops, topical corticosteroids, and if necessary, limited surgery like cryosurgery of turbinates, to relieve symptoms safely while considering fetal well-being.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antihistamines including newer agents: Incorrect. Safety of newer oral antihistamines in pregnancy is not well established and they should generally be avoided.

 

Option B. Oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Oral corticosteroids carry risks during pregnancy and are not preferred for routine management of rhinitis of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Surgical removal of nasal turbinates: Incorrect. Surgery is generally reserved for refractory cases and limited to safe procedures like cryosurgery; major surgical interventions are avoided during pregnancy.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Hormonal changes in pregnancy cause mucosal congestion leading to rhinitis symptoms.
  • Secondary infections or sinusitis can occur but should be treated cautiously.
  • Safety of fetal development is paramount in therapeutic choices during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinitis of pregnancy is managed primarily by local treatments such as limited topical nasal decongestants and corticosteroids, avoiding systemic medications with uncertain fetal safety.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Allergic reaction to airborne allergens triggered by sexual activity
Vasomotor rhinitis due to autonomic nervous system stimulation during sexual excitement
Infection-induced nasal mucosal swelling
Medication-induced rhinitis caused by contraceptives

questions.text: A 30-year-old man reports episodes of sudden nasal stuffiness that occur immediately following sexual excitement. He denies any nasal allergies or infections. Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vasomotor rhinitis due to autonomic nervous system stimulation during sexual excitement

 

Honeymoon rhinitis is a form of vasomotor rhinitis triggered by sexual excitement, which causes autonomic nervous system-mediated nasal mucosal vasodilation and stuffiness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic reaction to airborne allergens triggered by sexual activity: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated response to allergens, not typically triggered by sexual excitement.

 

Option C. Infection-induced nasal mucosal swelling: Incorrect. Infection causes inflammatory nasal symptoms but is not related to episodes linked with sexual activity.

 

Option D. Medication-induced rhinitis caused by contraceptives: Incorrect. Medication-induced rhinitis, such as from contraceptives, does not typically present immediately after sexual excitement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Honeymoon rhinitis is a type of vasomotor rhinitis where sexual excitement triggers autonomic stimulation leading to nasal stuffiness.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Oral antihistamines
Nasal corticosteroid sprays
Psychological counseling and imipramine
Nasal decongestant sprays

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of nasal congestion and watery nasal discharge that worsen during periods of anxiety and emotional stress. Allergy testing is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psychological counseling and imipramine

 

Emotional rhinitis is triggered by psychological states such as anxiety, tension, and grief. Treatment includes proper psychological counseling and medications like imipramine, which has both antidepressant and anticholinergic effects, helping reduce symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antihistamines: Incorrect. Oral antihistamines are effective in allergic rhinitis but not in emotional rhinitis, which lacks an allergic basis.

 

Option B. Nasal corticosteroid sprays: Incorrect. Nasal corticosteroids reduce inflammation in allergic rhinitis but are less effective in emotional rhinitis caused by psychological factors.

 

Option D. Nasal decongestant sprays: Incorrect. Nasal decongestants may relieve congestion temporarily but do not address the underlying psychological cause and may lead to rebound congestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emotional rhinitis results from psychological triggers and is best managed with psychological counseling and medications like imipramine having antidepressant and anticholinergic properties.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis due to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity
Hypothyroidism-induced rhinitis caused by autonomic imbalance
Chronic sinusitis due to bacterial infection
Vasomotor rhinitis due to autonomic nervous system instability

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent nasal stuffiness and frequent episodes of "colds" that do not respond to typical allergy treatments. She also reports fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On examination, she has dry skin and bradycardia. Which of the following best explains her nasal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypothyroidism-induced rhinitis caused by autonomic imbalance

 

Hypothyroidism leads to hypoactivity of the sympathetic nervous system with parasympathetic predominance, causing nasal stuffiness and recurrent "colds." Thyroid hormone replacement usually resolves these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis due to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis involves IgE-mediated immune response and typical allergic symptoms, which are absent here.

 

Option C. Chronic sinusitis due to bacterial infection: Incorrect. Chronic sinusitis presents with purulent nasal discharge and facial pain rather than persistent stuffiness related to systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis due to autonomic nervous system instability: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis is due to autonomic instability but is not specifically caused by hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:


Rhinitis due to hypothyroidism results from autonomic imbalance with decreased sympathetic activity and parasympathetic predominance, causing nasal stuffiness relieved by thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

Intranasal ipratropium bromide spray before meals
Oral corticosteroids during episodes
Nasal decongestant sprays used daily

questions.text: A 35-year-old man reports episodes of watery nasal discharge, nasal congestion, tearing, and facial flushing immediately after eating spicy foods. These symptoms are persistent and interfere with his daily activities. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate to prevent his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intranasal ipratropium bromide spray before meals

 

Gustatory rhinitis is caused by a cholinergic response to stimulation of sensory receptors on the palate by spicy foods containing capsaicin. Intranasal ipratropium bromide, an anticholinergic, effectively prevents rhinorrhea and nasal congestion when used a few minutes before meals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antihistamines taken before meals: Incorrect. Oral antihistamines are effective in allergic rhinitis but do not target cholinergic-mediated symptoms seen in gustatory rhinitis.

 

Option C. Oral corticosteroids during episodes: Incorrect. Oral corticosteroids are not indicated for gustatory rhinitis and have significant side effects.

 

Option D. Nasal decongestant sprays used daily: Incorrect. Nasal decongestants are not effective in preventing cholinergic symptoms and prolonged use can cause rebound congestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gustatory rhinitis caused by cholinergic stimulation from spicy foods is best prevented by intranasal ipratropium bromide spray administered prior to meals.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis due to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity
Nonairflow rhinitis due to loss of nasal airflow and vasomotor control
Infective rhinitis secondary to sinusitis
Vasomotor rhinitis caused by autonomic instability

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who underwent total laryngectomy six months ago complains of persistent nasal congestion and swollen nasal turbinates. Examination reveals hypertrophic turbinates but no signs of infection. Which of the following best explains his nasal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nonairflow rhinitis due to loss of nasal airflow and vasomotor control

 

Nonairflow rhinitis occurs in patients with altered nasal airflow, such as after laryngectomy or tracheostomy, leading to loss of vasomotor control and subsequent turbinate swelling. Similar changes occur in nasopharyngeal obstruction from choanal atresia or adenoidal hypertrophy, with infection risk due to impaired drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis due to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis involves immunologic hypersensitivity with typical symptoms and positive allergy tests, which are absent here.

 

Option C. Infective rhinitis secondary to sinusitis: Incorrect. Infective rhinitis presents with purulent discharge and systemic signs, not just turbinate hypertrophy without infection.

 

Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis caused by autonomic instability: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis involves autonomic instability but is unrelated to the loss of airflow seen post-laryngectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nonairflow rhinitis results from loss of nasal airflow and vasomotor control, causing turbinate hypertrophy commonly seen after laryngectomy, tracheostomy, or nasopharyngeal obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 171

choices.text: Sympathetic blockade by antihypertensive drugs leading to nasal mucosal congestion
Allergic reaction to propranolol causing nasal inflammation
Direct bacterial infection induced by contraceptive pills
Anticholinergic effect of propranolol causing nasal dryness

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive woman complains of persistent nasal stuffiness since starting her medications. Her treatment includes propranolol and oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism causing her nasal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sympathetic blockade by antihypertensive drugs leading to nasal mucosal congestion

 

Several antihypertensive drugs like reserpine, guanethidine, methyl dopa, and propranolol are sympathetic blocking agents. This blockade reduces sympathetic vasoconstriction, leading to nasal mucosal vasodilation and congestion causing nasal stuffiness. Additionally, contraceptive pills cause nasal obstruction due to estrogen-induced mucosal edema. Anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine mimic acetylcholine action and also cause nasal obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic reaction to propranolol causing nasal inflammation: Incorrect. Propranolol does not typically cause allergic rhinitis; nasal symptoms are due to autonomic effects, not allergy.

 

Option C. Direct bacterial infection induced by contraceptive pills: Incorrect. Contraceptive pills do not cause bacterial infections; nasal obstruction is due to hormonal effects.

 

Option D. Anticholinergic effect of propranolol causing nasal dryness: Incorrect. Propranolol does not have anticholinergic effects; nasal dryness is not a typical side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-induced rhinitis results from sympathetic blockade by antihypertensives and estrogen effects from contraceptive pills, causing nasal mucosal congestion and obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 170

choices.text: Continue nasal decongestant drops at higher frequency
Withdrawal of nasal decongestant drops and short course of systemic steroids
Immediate surgical removal of nasal turbinates
Initiate oral antihistamines and nasal corticosteroids without stopping nasal drops

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic nasal congestion has been using topical nasal decongestant drops daily for several weeks. He now complains of worsening nasal obstruction despite continued use. Examination reveals hypertrophied nasal turbinates. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Withdrawal of nasal decongestant drops and short course of systemic steroids

 

Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by rebound nasal congestion following excessive use of topical decongestants. Management involves withdrawal of nasal drops, administration of a short course of systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, and surgical reduction of hypertrophied turbinates if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue nasal decongestant drops at higher frequency: Incorrect. Continued or increased use of topical nasal decongestants worsens rebound congestion and perpetuates rhinitis medicamentosa.

 

Option C. Immediate surgical removal of nasal turbinates: Incorrect. Surgery is reserved for cases with persistent turbinate hypertrophy after medical treatment; it is not the first step.

 

Option D. Initiate oral antihistamines and nasal corticosteroids without stopping nasal drops: Incorrect. Nasal corticosteroids and antihistamines can be used but nasal decongestants must be stopped to break the vicious cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinitis medicamentosa results from excessive use of topical nasal decongestants causing rebound congestion and is managed primarily by withdrawal of nasal drops and short-term systemic steroids.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 170

choices.text: IgE-mediated mast cell activation; nasal polypectomy
Autonomic imbalance causing parasympathetic overactivity; Vidian neurectomy
Chronic bacterial infection causing mucosal swelling; functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)
Structural nasal deviation causing airflow turbulence; septoplasty

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with year-round nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea, and sneezing. Allergy testing is negative. Symptoms worsen with sudden temperature changes. Examination shows congested nasal mucosa. Which of the following explains the pathogenesis of her condition, and what surgical option can be considered if medical therapy fails?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autonomic imbalance causing parasympathetic overactivity; Vidian neurectomy

 

Vasomotor rhinitis results from autonomic nervous system imbalance with parasympathetic overactivity causing vasodilation and sinusoidal engorgement of nasal mucosa. The Vidian nerve, formed by parasympathetic fibers from the greater superficial petrosal nerve (branch of facial nerve) and sympathetic fibers from the deep petrosal nerve, can be surgically sectioned (Vidian neurectomy) to reduce excessive nasal secretions and congestion refractory to medical therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgE-mediated mast cell activation; nasal polypectomy: Incorrect. IgE-mediated mast cell activation is characteristic of allergic rhinitis, which is ruled out by negative allergy testing. Nasal polypectomy treats nasal polyps, not vasomotor rhinitis.

 

Option C. Chronic bacterial infection causing mucosal swelling; functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS): Incorrect. Chronic bacterial infections cause different symptoms and are managed by FESS only if sinus disease is present.

 

Option D. Structural nasal deviation causing airflow turbulence; septoplasty: Incorrect. Structural abnormalities cause obstruction but do not explain autonomic imbalance or negative allergy tests.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Medical management includes avoidance of triggers (temperature, humidity), antihistamines, decongestants, steroids, and tranquilizers.
  • The Vidian nerve carries parasympathetic fibers that stimulate nasal gland secretion; its section reduces symptoms in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vasomotor rhinitis is caused by autonomic imbalance with parasympathetic overactivity leading to nasal congestion; refractory cases may benefit from Vidian neurectomy, which interrupts parasympathetic innervation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 170
